**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How often does a supernova occur in the observable universe? Options: A. Every minute, B. Every second or so, C. Every hour, D. Every day Correct Option: None
Question 2: How often does a supernova occur in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way? Options: A. Every 1 to 5 years, B. Every 25 to 50 years, C. Every 100 to 200 years, D. Every 500 to 1000 years Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why is it difficult to watch a supernova from its first violent moments? Options: A. Because supernovae are too far away, B. Because supernovae are too rare, C. Because we would need to have our best telescopes focused on the right star at precisely the right time, D. Because supernovae are too bright Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of particles reaches Earth before photons in the event of a supernova? Options: A. Electrons, B. Protons, C. Neutrinos, D. Quarks Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. Type 1 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel, while Type 2 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star, B. Type 1 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star, while Type 2 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel, C. Type 1 is more violent than Type 2, D. Type 2 is more violent than Type 1 Correct Option: None
Question 6: What percentage of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova consists of photons? Options: A. 1%, B. 10%, C. 50%, D. 99% Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the project that aims to detect supernovae by monitoring neutrino bursts? Options: A. SNEWS, B. Supernova Watch, C. Neutrino Alert System, D. Galactic Monitor Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do neutrino detectors contribute to the SNEWS project? Options: A. They send messages to a central computer in New York when they detect a supernova, B. They provide distance and direction information to help locate the supernova, C. They trigger an alert warning that a supernova is imminent when multiple detectors receive similar signals, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: When did the last supernova that sent detectable neutrinos to Earth occur? Options: A. 1977, B. 1987, C. 1997, D. 2007 Correct Option: None
Question 10: How long did it take for the neutrinos from the 1987 supernova to reach Earth before the visible light? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 3 hours, C. 10 hours, D. 24 hours Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What percentage of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova consists of photons? 

Although this question does not directly ask about neutrinos, it is related to the distribution of energy in a supernova explosion, which is the same topic as the ground truth MCQ. The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ (99% of energy is expelled as neutrinos) is implied by the correct answer to Question 6 (1% of energy consists of photons), as the remaining 99% is neutrinos.

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match among the generated MCQs for the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A supernova is defined as _____.
Options: A. Meteor, B. Satellite crash, C. Planet explosion, D. Death of a star
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How often does a supernova occur in the observable universe? Options: A. Every minute, B. Every second or so, C. Every hour, D. Every day Correct Option: None
Question 2: How often does a supernova occur in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way? Options: A. Every 1 to 5 years, B. Every 25 to 50 years, C. Every 100 to 200 years, D. Every 500 to 1000 years Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why is it difficult to watch a supernova from its first violent moments? Options: A. Because supernovae are too far away, B. Because supernovae are too rare, C. Because we would need to have our best telescopes focused on the right star at precisely the right time, D. Because supernovae are too bright Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of particles reaches Earth before photons in the event of a supernova? Options: A. Electrons, B. Protons, C. Neutrinos, D. Quarks Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. Type 1 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel, while Type 2 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star, B. Type 1 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star, while Type 2 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel, C. Type 1 is more violent than Type 2, D. Type 2 is more violent than Type 1 Correct Option: None
Question 6: What percentage of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova consists of photons? Options: A. 1%, B. 10%, C. 50%, D. 99% Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the project that aims to detect supernovae by monitoring neutrino bursts? Options: A. SNEWS, B. Supernova Watch, C. Neutrino Alert System, D. Galactic Monitor Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do neutrino detectors contribute to the SNEWS project? Options: A. They send messages to a central computer in New York when they detect a supernova, B. They provide distance and direction information to help locate the supernova, C. They trigger an alert warning that a supernova is imminent when multiple detectors receive similar signals, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: When did the last supernova that sent detectable neutrinos to Earth occur? Options: A. 1977, B. 1987, C. 1997, D. 2007 Correct Option: None
Question 10: How long did it take for the neutrinos from the 1987 supernova to reach Earth before the visible light? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 3 hours, C. 10 hours, D. 24 hours Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can try to find the one that is most closely related.

The ground truth MCQ asks for the definition of a supernova. While none of the generated MCQs ask for a definition, Question 5 comes closest to discussing the concept of supernovae and their types. However, it does not provide a definition.

If I had to choose, I would say that Question 5 is the most similar, but it's still not a good match.

Index: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the last observable supernova?
Options: A. 1987, B. 1999, C. 1978, D. 1969
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The three indices of the fraud triangle are pressure, opportunity and _____.
Options: A. Critical thinking, B. Rationalization, C. Justification, D. Validation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the estimated total amount of money lost by organizations worldwide to fraud in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to the fraud triangle model developed by criminologist Donald Cressey, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and greed, B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, C. Pressure, motivation, and rationalization, D. Opportunity, motivation, and greed Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is often the motivating factor that leads someone to engage in fraud? Options: A. Personal gain, B. Pressure, such as a personal debt or an earnings quota, C. Opportunity to commit and conceal fraud, D. Rationalization that the fraud is victimless Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a common type of fraud that may not register as such to the perpetrator? Options: A. Embezzlement, B. Fudging time sheets or expense reports, C. Pyramid schemes, D. False insurance claims Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the reason for the bankruptcy of Italian dairy food giant Parmalat in 2003? Options: A. Corporate greed, B. Fabrication of a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements, C. Poor management, D. Economic downturn Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who embezzled over 53 million dollars during her time as City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. Rita Crundwell, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Donald Cressey, D. Unknown Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why did Rita Crundwell feel entitled to embezzle money from the city of Dixon? Options: A. She felt underpaid and overworked, B. She wanted to fund her lavish lifestyle and horse breeding business, C. She wanted to help the city's economy, D. She was in financial need Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is a common misconception about fraud? Options: A. That it is a victimless crime, B. That it only affects corporations and civic institutions, C. That it is only committed by individuals, D. That it is always obvious and devastating Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the result of Bernie Madoff's fraudulent activities? Options: A. Thousands of people lost their jobs, B. Thousands of people lost their life savings, C. Companies raised their prices to offset losses, D. The economy experienced a downturn Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who ultimately bears the cost of fraud? Options: A. Corporations and civic institutions, B. Governments and non-profits, C. Individuals who commit fraud, D. Real people, such as employees, customers, and taxpayers Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the question format is different (the ground truth MCQ asks for the third index of the fraud triangle, while the generated MCQ asks for all three conditions), the content and options of Question 2 align with the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 2 (B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization) matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (B. Rationalization).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2

and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

Options: A. 2.5 billion, B. 3.7 trillion, C. 100 billion, D. 10 trillion
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Parmalat falsified financial statements to hide losses from their subsidiaries.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the estimated total amount of money lost by organizations worldwide to fraud in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to the fraud triangle model developed by criminologist Donald Cressey, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and greed, B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, C. Pressure, motivation, and rationalization, D. Opportunity, motivation, and greed Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is often the motivating factor that leads someone to engage in fraud? Options: A. Personal gain, B. Pressure, such as a personal debt or an earnings quota, C. Opportunity to commit and conceal fraud, D. Rationalization that the fraud is victimless Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a common type of fraud that may not register as such to the perpetrator? Options: A. Embezzlement, B. Fudging time sheets or expense reports, C. Pyramid schemes, D. False insurance claims Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the reason for the bankruptcy of Italian dairy food giant Parmalat in 2003? Options: A. Corporate greed, B. Fabrication of a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements, C. Poor management, D. Economic downturn Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who embezzled over 53 million dollars during her time as City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. Rita Crundwell, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Donald Cressey, D. Unknown Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why did Rita Crundwell feel entitled to embezzle money from the city of Dixon? Options: A. She felt underpaid and overworked, B. She wanted to fund her lavish lifestyle and horse breeding business, C. She wanted to help the city's economy, D. She was in financial need Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is a common misconception about fraud? Options: A. That it is a victimless crime, B. That it only affects corporations and civic institutions, C. That it is only committed by individuals, D. That it is always obvious and devastating Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the result of Bernie Madoff's fraudulent activities? Options: A. Thousands of people lost their jobs, B. Thousands of people lost their life savings, C. Companies raised their prices to offset losses, D. The economy experienced a downturn Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who ultimately bears the cost of fraud? Options: A. Corporations and civic institutions, B. Governments and non-profits, C. Individuals who commit fraud, D. Real people, such as employees, customers, and taxpayers Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question asks about the reason for the bankruptcy of Italian dairy food giant Parmalat in 2003, and one of the options (B) specifically mentions the fabrication of a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements, which is the same information mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. 

Although the question and options are not identical, the content and intent of Question 5 are the most similar to the ground truth MCQ among the provided options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 40 million, B. 53 million, C. 5 million, D. 10 million
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people

to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities

that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller

over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
Options: A. -9.8 meters per second squared, B. -4.9 meters per second squared, C. -32 meters per second squared, D. -16 meters per second squared
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the transcript, what is the approximate human limit for hang time on a flat surface? Options: A. 0.5 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the gravitational acceleration of the Earth, according to the transcript? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 24.92 meters per second squared, D. 4.51 meters per second squared Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the equation that models hang time, as stated in the transcript? Options: A. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time, B. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + 0.5 x Gravitational Acceleration x Time^2, C. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time - Gravitational Acceleration x Time, D. Height = Initial Height - Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is Michael Jordan's initial vertical velocity when jumping for his free throw dunk? Options: A. 2.51 meters per second, B. 4.51 meters per second, C. 6.51 meters per second, D. 8.51 meters per second Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the shape of the relationship between height and time spent in the air, according to the transcript? Options: A. Linear, B. Quadratic (parabola), C. Exponential, D. Circular Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the maximum height Michael Jordan reaches during his free throw dunk? Options: A. 0.5 meters, B. 1.038 meters, C. 2 meters, D. 3 meters Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the gravitational acceleration on Venus, according to the transcript? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 24.92 meters per second squared, D. 4.51 meters per second squared Correct Option: None
Question 8: According to the transcript, how long would Michael Jordan's hang time be on Jupiter? Options: A. 0.41 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the gravitational acceleration on the moon, according to the transcript? Options: A. Not explicitly stated, but implied to be much weaker than Earth's, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 24.92 meters per second squared, D. 8.87 meters per second squared Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, how long would Michael Jordan's hang time be on the moon? Options: A. 1 second, B. 2 seconds, C. 3 seconds, D. Over 5.5 seconds Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (acceleration due to gravity on Earth) and options (includes the correct answer of 9.8 meters per second squared). Although the generated MCQ does not explicitly state the negative sign for the acceleration, the question content and options are similar enough to make it the most matching generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height

of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model

to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is a possible equation that could model the relationship between height and hang time for someone on Venus?
Options: A. h=8.87t^2-4.5t, B. h=-8.87t^2+4.5t, C. h=-4.44t^2+4.5t, D. h=4.44t^2-4.5t
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the transcript, what is the approximate human limit for hang time on a flat surface? Options: A. 0.5 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the gravitational acceleration of the Earth, according to the transcript? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 24.92 meters per second squared, D. 4.51 meters per second squared Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the equation that models hang time, as stated in the transcript? Options: A. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time, B. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + 0.5 x Gravitational Acceleration x Time^2, C. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time - Gravitational Acceleration x Time, D. Height = Initial Height - Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is Michael Jordan's initial vertical velocity when jumping for his free throw dunk? Options: A. 2.51 meters per second, B. 4.51 meters per second, C. 6.51 meters per second, D. 8.51 meters per second Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of function is the relationship between height and hang time?
Options: A. Linear, B. Exponential, C. Quadratic, D. Increasing
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 3: What is the equation that models hang time, as stated in the transcript? Options: A. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time, B. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time + 0.5 x Gravitational Acceleration x Time^2, C. Height = Initial Height + Initial Velocity x Time - Gravitational Acceleration x Time, D. Height = Initial Height - Initial Velocity x Time + Gravitational Acceleration x Time Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is Michael Jordan's initial vertical velocity when jumping for his free throw dunk? Options: A. 2.51 meters per second, B. 4.51 meters per second, C. 6.51 meters per second, D. 8.51 meters per second Correct Option: None

towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,

that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds

get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

Correct Option: C

must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Gluten can be found in which type of grains?
Options: A. Wheat, B. Rye, C. Barley, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in certain grains, D. A type of enzyme that breaks down proteins Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which grains are gluten typically found in? Options: A. Rice, quinoa, and oats, B. Wheat, rye, and barley, C. Corn, soybeans, and wheat, D. Rye, barley, and oats Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of gluten in food? Options: A. To provide nutritional value, B. To add flavor to food, C. To give food its elastic consistency and chewiness, D. To preserve food Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is wheat allergy? Options: A. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, B. A condition where the immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is celiac disease? Options: A. A type of wheat allergy, B. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. Medication to reduce inflammation, B. A gluten-free diet, C. Surgery to repair the small intestine, D. Avoiding wheat and other grains Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A type of wheat allergy, B. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, C. A condition where people experience symptoms when eating foods with gluten, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy, D. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars Correct Option: None
Question 8: How is non-celiac gluten sensitivity diagnosed? Options: A. Through a blood test, B. Through a tissue test, C. Based on the development of symptoms and improvement on a gluten-free diet, D. Through a biopsy Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. A phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does, B. A phenomenon where a person believes something will have a positive effect, and because of that belief, it does, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why might "wheat intolerance" be a more accurate term than "non-celiac gluten sensitivity"? Options: A. Because gluten is the primary cause of symptoms, B. Because wheat is the primary grain that contains gluten, C. Because the problems people develop when eating wheat and other grains are not exclusively due to gluten, D. Because gluten is found in all types of grains Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: "Which grains are gluten typically found in? Options: A. Rice, quinoa, and oats, B. Wheat, rye, and barley, C. Corn, soybeans, and wheat, D. Rye, barley, and oats". 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the types of grains that contain gluten. The correct option in the generated MCQ is B. Wheat, rye, and barley, which matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, D. All of the above (wheat, rye, and barley).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An inherited disease in which eating gluten inflames and damages the lining of the small intenstine is called:
Options: A. A wheat allergy, B. Anaphylaxis, C. Celiac disease, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in certain grains, D. A type of enzyme that breaks down proteins Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which grains are gluten typically found in? Options: A. Rice, quinoa, and oats, B. Wheat, rye, and barley, C. Corn, soybeans, and wheat, D. Rye, barley, and oats Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of gluten in food? Options: A. To provide nutritional value, B. To add flavor to food, C. To give food its elastic consistency and chewiness, D. To preserve food Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is wheat allergy? Options: A. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, B. A condition where the immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is celiac disease? Options: A. A type of wheat allergy, B. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. Medication to reduce inflammation, B. A gluten-free diet, C. Surgery to repair the small intestine, D. Avoiding wheat and other grains Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A type of wheat allergy, B. An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, C. A condition where people experience symptoms when eating foods with gluten, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy, D. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars Correct Option: None
Question 8: How is non-celiac gluten sensitivity diagnosed? Options: A. Through a blood test, B. Through a tissue test, C. Based on the development of symptoms and improvement on a gluten-free diet, D. Through a biopsy Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. A phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does, B. A phenomenon where a person believes something will have a positive effect, and because of that belief, it does, C. A type of intolerance to wheat sugars, D. A type of autoimmune disease Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why might "wheat intolerance" be a more accurate term than "non-celiac gluten sensitivity"? Options: A. Because gluten is the primary cause of symptoms, B. Because wheat is the primary grain that contains gluten, C. Because the problems people develop when eating wheat and other grains are not exclusively due to gluten, D. Because gluten is found in all types of grains Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is celiac disease? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content, as both questions ask about the definition of celiac disease. The options in Question 5 also align with the ground truth MCQ, with option B in Question 5 matching the correct option C in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. A wheat allergy, B. Anaphylaxis, C. Celiac disease, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity
Correct Option: D

Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,

about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following

particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for

than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based

and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity

in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming

Options: A. Fermentation by bacteria, B. Production of short chain fatty acids and gases, C. Both A and B, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

Question: What happens when the human intestines cannot break down or absorb fructans?
Options: A. They are absorbed into the bloodstream, B. They are fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids and gases, C. They are eliminated through the kidneys, D. They are stored in the liver

Correct Option: B

Options: A. Bad press, B. A placebo effect, C. Sensitivity, D. Nocebo effect
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which disease gives off the smell of freshly baked brown bread?
Options: A. Smallpox, B. Tuberculosis, C. Typhoid fever, D. Ebola
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set.
